p: The BooT-PCA method is based on the possibility to track a grain boundary observed as density variations in successive detector hit maps (see Fig 4), in order to extract the position and mass-to-charge ratio of the atoms in the specimenâ€™s space that belong to this specific grain boundary. Because the commercially available software allows to routinely retrieve RGB (red-green-blue) detector hit maps, the input in BooT-PCA is a series of such images instead of the raw detector hits. BooT-PCA combines the boosting tracker and principal component analysis (PCA) for automatically extracting the spatial coordinates of grain boundaries. We show here how additional filters can be introduced if necessary, with an example of a filter based on the Hough transform. The general framework of BooT-PCA is laid out in the flowchart displayed in Fig 5.
